title: Suggestions for a carved, industrial serif for text.
content:
Hi Team!

I would really appreciate your advice. My client is looking for a body copy face that that gives a sense of being 'carved' on the page. She's looking for a sense of ancient.

Further, she described it as kind of industrial, elegant...not a warm, personal, intimate feeling, but more industrial, with a sense of iron...but not too austere...

For chapter headers she's liking Goudy Trajan, but personally, I think its tired so we're looking for a replacement for that as well.

The book contains poetry, so for the most part, the text will not be dense on the page.

Here's her current choice, of which I was no part. Any ideas?

Thank you!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804063717im_/http:/typophile.com/files/photo_3817.JPG)
author: malbright

comments.content:
Very subjective criteria for the body text. I hesitate make suggestions based on them and I trust you are familiar with the common candidates. A less known prospect might be Aragon by Canada Type [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/aragon/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804063717/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/aragon/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/aragon/") Or you might browse through some of the suggestions recently posted in the long running thread Best Serif Ever [http://typophile.com/node/27736](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804063717/http:/typophile.com/node/27736 "http://typophile.com/node/27736")  
As for the Trajan replacement, one possibility that I like is Centaur, an elegant font with a sculptural feeling  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/centaur/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804063717/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/centaur/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/centaur/")  
Don
Thank you, Don! I know what you mean about that criteria. That's why this is driving me nuts. I have no idea.

Michael,
